questions.text: Most common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The image provided is an endoscopic view of the nasopharynx. The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, which is located posterior to the torus tubarius. The torus tubarius is an elevation formed by the cartilaginous portion of the Eustachian tube, and the fossa of Rosenmüller is the recess behind this elevation. Site number 2 in the image corresponds to the fossa of Rosenmüller, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: This represents the posterior pharyngeal wall, which is not the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option C. 3: This represents another area of the nasopharynx but is not the typical site for the origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Option D. 4: This represents the opening of the Eustachian tube. While nasopharyngeal carcinoma can affect this area, it is not the most common primary site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius in the nasopharynx.

choices.text: Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B

questions.text: All of the following statements about the pathogenesis of Clostridium difficile-associated pseudomembranous enterocolitis are true, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B

 

Explanation:

 

The statement that "Toxin A is more potent than Toxin B" is false. Both toxins are significant virulence factors in C. difficile infection, but Toxin B is actually considered more potent in causing disease. Both toxins act by glycosylating GTP-binding proteins that regulate the cellular actin cytoskeleton, leading to disruption of the epithelial cell barrier. While Toxin A was historically thought to be the primary toxin, more recent understanding suggests that Toxin B plays the more crucial role in pathogenesis, with some pathogenic strains producing only Toxin B and not Toxin A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exotoxin mediated: This statement is true. C. difficile pathogenesis is indeed exotoxin mediated. The bacteria produce two major exotoxins (Toxin A and Toxin B) that are responsible for the clinical manifestations of disease, including pseudomembrane formation and diarrhea.

 

Option B. Toxin A is an enterotoxin: This statement is true. Toxin A functions primarily as an enterotoxin, affecting intestinal epithelial cells, disrupting tight junctions between cells, and causing fluid secretion in the intestine.

 

Option C. Toxin B is a cytotoxin: This statement is true. Toxin B functions primarily as a cytotoxin, causing direct damage to cells by disrupting the cytoskeleton after glycosylation of GTP-binding proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile causes pseudomembranous colitis through the action of two major exotoxins (Toxin A and Toxin B) that disrupt the cytoskeleton of intestinal epithelial cells, with Toxin B being more potent than Toxin A, contradicting earlier assumptions about their relative importance in pathogenesis.

questions.text: A pediatric surgeon is planning the optimal timing for cleft palate surgery on a young patient. For the repair of the soft palate, at what age should the surgery ideally be performed? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 months

 

Soft palate repair is typically performed between 3 to 6 months of age. This early intervention is crucial as it facilitates better outcomes in terms of speech development and minimizes the risks associated with feeding difficulties. Early repair allows for more normal development of speech patterns as the child grows, which is vital for effective communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The timing of cleft palate surgery –

 

  • For the soft palate, surgery is ideally conducted at 3 -6 months
  • For the hard palate repair is done at 12-15 months.

choices.text: Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

questions.text: What is the cause of the condition given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

 

The above image shows washerwoman's feet/ washerwoman's skin. It is seen in a case of immersion in water (both antemortem as well as postmortem drowning). It denotes skin maceration or swelling and wrinkling of the skin due to water absorption. Following changes are seen in washerwoman skin:

 

  • Wrinkling: After 3 hrs of immersion
  • Soddening (filled with water): After 12 hrs of immersion
  • Bleaching (whitening): After 36 hrs of immersion
  • Peeling: after 72 hrs of immersion

 

In the image, bleaching can be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic neuropathy: Diabetic neuropathy typically presents with sensory deficits, pain, or ulcers but does not cause the skin changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Hanging: Hanging does not cause the specific wrinkling and bleaching of the skin seen in the image.

 

Option D. Burns of foot: Burns would result in charring, blistering, and other thermal injuries, not the wrinkling and bleaching seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's feet (or skin) is characterized by swelling, wrinkling, and bleaching due to prolonged immersion in water, typically observed after more than 36 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a growth factor promoting proto-oncogene?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF-beta

 

Transforming Growth Factor-beta (TGF-beta) does not promote proto-oncogenes. Instead, TGF-beta plays a crucial role in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing by promoting the deposition of fibrous tissue. TGF-beta acts similarly to interleukin-10, reducing inflammation and aiding in tissue repair. Unlike other growth factors such as TGF-alpha, PDGF, and FGF, which are involved in cell proliferation and can promote proto-oncogenes, TGF-beta primarily functions to control and reduce inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TGF-alpha: Incorrect. TGF-alpha is a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is involved in cell proliferation.

 

Option B. PDGF: Incorrect. Platelet-Derived Growth Factor (PDGF) is a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is significant in the pathogenesis of brain tumors and other cell growth processes.

 

Option C. FGF: Incorrect. Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF) is another growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is involved in various cellular processes, including cell growth and development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TGF-beta is not a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes; instead, it is involved in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of seeing snakes crawling and an inability to recognize his own family members. He reports his last alcohol intake was 48 hours ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delirium tremens

 

This case presents with classic features of delirium tremens:

 

  • Onset 48 hours after last alcohol intake (characteristic 48–72-hour onset)
  • Visual hallucinations (snakes crawling)
  • Disorientation (inability to recognize family members) 

 

Delirium tremens is characterized by confusion, disorientation to time/place/person, and hallucinations (usually visual). It typically appears 48-72 hours after the last alcohol intake and represents a severe form of alcohol withdrawal.

 

Alcohol Withdrawal Symptoms

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol-Induced Psychosis:

 

  • Alcohol-induced psychosis involves hallucinations and delusions but NO disorientation.
  • The presence of disorientation in this case strongly suggests delirium tremens rather than alcohol-induced psychosis.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia:

 

  • Schizophrenia is not associated with acute alcohol withdrawal.
  • Hallucinations in schizophrenia are typically auditory, rather than visual, and there is no acute disorientation as seen in Delirium Tremens.

 

Option D. Alcoholic Hallucinosis:

 

  • Alcoholic hallucinosis is characterized by persistent auditory hallucinations, typically without disorientation or disturbances of consciousness. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium Tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome presenting 48-72 hours after last alcohol intake, characterized by confusion, disorientation, and hallucinations.

questions.text: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subcutaneous nodules

 

Subcutaneous nodules are the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), occurring in 20-30% of cases, usually in seropositive patients. These nodules often appear on extensor surfaces, such as the elbows, or in other areas subject to pressure, and they can also manifest in internal organs like the lungs and heart. Their presence correlates with a more severe disease course and is associated with specific RA antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sjogren's syndrome: While Sjogren's syndrome (secondary to RA) can occur and manifests as keratoconjunctivitis sicca, it is less common than subcutaneous nodules as an extra-articular feature.

 

Option C. Felty's syndrome: This is a rare complication of long-standing RA, characterized by neutropenia and splenomegaly, and occurs in about 1% of patients.

 

Option D. Vasculitis: Cutaneous vasculitis may present in RA but is less frequently observed compared to subcutaneous nodules. It includes symptoms like ulcers and purpura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information Deformities

 

1. Pseudo Deformities

 

 

2. True Deformities

 

 

Reference - Pocket Medicine 8E/2022

questions.text: Which of the following does not contain peptidoglycan in its cell wall? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Mycoplasma

 

Explanation:

 

Mycoplasma is the correct answer because it is a naturally occurring bacteria that completely lacks a cell wall. Since peptidoglycan is a major structural component of bacterial cell walls, Mycoplasma does not contain peptidoglycan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlamydia - Chlamydia are bacteria that possess cell walls containing peptidoglycan, though their cell walls may have structural differences from typical bacteria.

 

Option C. Rickettsia - Rickettsia are bacteria with cell walls containing peptidoglycan. As gram-negative bacteria, they have a thin peptidoglycan layer between their inner and outer 

membranes.

 

Option D. Virus - While viruses don't contain peptidoglycan, this answer is incorrect because viruses don't have cell walls at all. Viruses are not cellular organisms - they consist of genetic material enclosed in a protein coat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma represents a unique group of bacteria that naturally lacks cell walls, making them intrinsically resistant to antibiotics like penicillins that target cell wall synthesis. This characteristic distinguishes them from other bacteria which contain peptidoglycan in their cell walls.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2 concentration

 

Methods to confirm endotracheal intubation:

  • X-ray chest
  • Auscultation
  • End-tidal CO2 concentration
  • Chest rise

 

This is considered the best method to confirm ETT placement in real-time. Capnography measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the exhaled breath. When the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea, it will produce a waveform with a consistent and relatively high end-tidal CO2 concentration. In contrast, if the ETT is in the esophagus or there is an airway obstruction, the end-tidal CO2 concentration will be lower or absent, providing immediate feedback to the anesthesiologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray chest: While a chest X-ray can confirm the placement of the ETT, it is not a practical or immediate method for confirming tube placement during intubation. X-rays are typically used for confirmation after intubation.

 

Option B. Auscultation: Auscultation involves listening to breath sounds over the chest and epigastrium to assess tube placement. While it can be a useful method, it may not always be reliable, especially in noisy clinical environments, and it may not detect esophageal intubation or partial airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Observing chest rise can be helpful, but it is not as reliable as capnography. In some cases, chest rise may be present even if the ETT is incorrectly placed in the esophagus, especially in cases of esophageal intubation with positive-pressure ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gold standard for confirming ETT placement is indeed the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography.
  • It provides real-time feedback and is considered a more reliable method compared to other options, ensuring that the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea and the patient is being ventilated effectively.

choices.text: 200 mg

questions.text: The maximum dose of PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 mg

 

Explanation:

 

Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2α), also known as carboprost, is used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony. The therapeutic regimen and maximum dosage are crucial for effective management and patient safety.

 

  • Dose and Administration: The approved dose for treating uterine atony with PGF2α is 0.25 mg administered intramuscularly (IM).
  • Maximum Dose: The maximum cumulative dose is 2 mg. This is achieved by administering a total of 8 doses of 0.25 mg each.
  • Dosing Interval: These doses can be repeated at intervals of 15 to 90 minutes, depending on the clinical response and the patient's condition.

 

Contraindications

 

  • Bronchial Asthma: PGF2α can cause bronchoconstriction, which makes it contraindicated in patients with bronchial asthma.
  • Suspected Amniotic Fluid Embolism: Due to its potential to cause pulmonary airway and vascular constriction, it is also contraindicated in cases of suspected amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.25 mg: This is the single dose administered IM but not the cumulative maximum dose.

 

Option C. 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and not clinically recommended or safe.

 

Option D. 200 mg: This dose is not applicable for human use and is far beyond the safe and recommended limits.

 

Educational Objective

 

The maximum dose of prostaglandin F2 alpha in the management of postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg, administered in 0.25 mg increments intramuscularly.

 

Ref: Page no 480, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: To assess mobility of cervical spine
To assess mobility of atlanto-axial joint
For assessment of free rotation of neck before intubation
Inspection of oral cavity before intubation

questions.text: What is the main use of Mallampati Grading? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inspection of oral cavity before intubation.

 

Mallampati grading is a standardized system used to classify and evaluate the visibility of oropharyngeal structures. It involves asking the patient to sit upright, open their mouth as wide as possible, and protrude the tongue without phonation. Based on the structures visible, patients are classified into four grades (I-IV). This examination helps predict potential difficulties with laryngoscopy and intubation by assessing the relative size of the tongue compared to the oral cavity

 

 

Mallampati Score/Grading for Assessment of Airway

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. To assess mobility of cervical spine: Cervical spine mobility is assessed separately through neck extension and flexion tests, not through Mallampati grading.

 

Option B. To assess mobility of atlanto-axial joint: This is evaluated through specific neck mobility tests, not through oral cavity examination.

 

Option C. For assessment of free rotation of neck before intubation: Neck rotation is part of the overall airway assessment but is separate from Mallampati grading, which focuses solely on the oral cavity structures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mallampati grading is a standardized technique for evaluating oropharyngeal structures during preoperative airway assessment and serves as one of the key predictors of difficult laryngoscopy and intubation.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) weakness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyper-reflexia

 

Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) lesions are associated with a specific set of clinical features due to the disruption of the central motor pathways that originate in the cerebral cortex and descend through the brainstem and spinal cord to synapse on the lower motor neurons. The key features of UMN lesions include:

 

  • Hyper-reflexia: This is characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. The loss of inhibitory modulation from the cortex leads to an overactive reflex arc.
  • Spasticity: Increased muscle tone that is velocity-dependent, often seen in conjunction with hyper-reflexia.
  • Babinski sign: An abnormal reflex where the big toe extends upward when the sole of the foot is stimulated.
  • No significant muscle atrophy: While mild disuse atrophy can occur over time, it is not as pronounced as in lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions.
  • No fasciculations: Fasciculations, or spontaneous contractions of muscle fibers, are indicative of LMN lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrophy: Significant muscle atrophy is a hallmark of LMN lesions due to denervation of the muscles. It is not typically seen in UMN lesions except for mild disuse atrophy.

 

Option C. Rigidity: Rigidity is associated with extrapyramidal disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, and is characterized by increased muscle tone that is uniform and not velocity-dependent.

 

Option D. Fasciculations: Fasciculations are indicative of LMN lesions and result from spontaneous depolarization of lower motor neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) weakness is hyper-reflexia, characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. This occurs due to the loss of inhibitory control from the brain on the reflex arcs in the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which protein, having structural homology with plasminogen, is responsible for myocardial infarction and stroke? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LP(a)

 

Explanation:


LP(a) or Lipoprotein(a) consists of one mole of LDL attached to one mole of apo(a). The apo(a) component shows structural homologies to plasminogen, which is clinically significant. This similarity to plasminogen, a key protein in the fibrinolytic system, allows LP(a) to inhibit fibrinolysis (the normal breakdown of blood clots). Consequently, LP(a) promotes both atherosclerosis and thrombosis, significantly increasing the risk of premature coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, and stroke.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HDL: High-density lipoprotein is actually protective against cardiovascular disease. It removes cholesterol from peripheral tissues and has antiatherogenic properties without any structural similarity to plasminogen.

 

Option C. LDL:  While low-density lipoprotein contributes to atherosclerosis by delivering cholesterol to tissues, it doesn't have structural homology with plasminogen.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is an amino acid that at elevated levels is associated with increased cardiovascular risk, but it's not a protein and does not have structural homology with plasminogen.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

LP(a) contributes to cardiovascular disease through a unique dual mechanism: promoting atherosclerosis like LDL, while also increasing thrombosis risk due to its structural homology with plasminogen that inhibits normal fibrinolysis.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  • Definition: Nuchal translucency refers to the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • Significance: An increased NT measurement is associated with an increased risk for fetal aneuploidy (such as Down syndrome) and various structural anomalies including cardiovascular defects, hydrops fetalis, and cystic hygroma.

 

Timing:

 

  • NT is measured between 11 weeks and 13 weeks 6 days (or 11-14 weeks) of gestation. This time frame is critical as it ensures the accuracy of the measurement and its correlation with potential anomalies.

 

Measurement Criteria:

 

  • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Should be between 45-84 mm.
  • Fetal Position: Fetus should be in the mid-sagittal plane and in a neutral position.
  • Image Quality: The image must be magnified, and the widest space should be measured.
  • Caliper Placement: The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space, ensuring the amnion is seen separately.

 

Screening Efficiency:

 

  • NT Alone: Provides a 65% detection rate for Down syndrome.
  • Combined Test: When combined with the Dual Marker test (beta hCG and PAPP-A), the detection rate for Down syndrome improves to 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6-8 weeks: This is too early for accurate NT measurement.

 

Option C. 14-16 weeks: This is beyond the optimal time frame for NT evaluation, reducing the effectiveness of the screening.

 

Option D. 16-20 weeks: This period is too late for NT measurement, which should be performed in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation is between 11-14 weeks of gestation.

 

 

Ref: Page no 860, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient is found to have a solitary thyroid nodule. What is the first step in his management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Thyroid profile/TSH

 

The initial evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule begins with a thyroid profile, specifically measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. This is the first step because the TSH test helps determine whether the nodule is functioning (producing thyroid hormone) or non-functioning. If TSH is suppressed, indicating a hyperfunctioning (autonomous) nodule, further evaluation with a radionuclide scan may be appropriate to assess whether the nodule is "hot" (functioning). If TSH is normal or elevated, the next steps typically include an ultrasound (USG) of the neck and possibly fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy, depending on ultrasound findings. The management plan is tailored based on these initial results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radioiodine with I123: This diagnostic scan is typically used after initial thyroid function tests suggest a hyperfunctioning nodule. It is not the first step.

 

Option C. Radioiodine with I131: I131 is primarily used for therapeutic purposes, such as treating hyperthyroidism or certain types of thyroid cancer, not for initial diagnostic evaluation of a thyroid nodule.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): CECT is not routinely used as the first step in the evaluation of thyroid nodules due to its limited ability to characterize thyroid nodules compared to ultrasound and potential interference with subsequent radioactive iodine therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of a solitary thyroid nodule is to assess thyroid function with a TSH test. This guides further diagnostic and management strategies based on whether the nodule is functioning or not.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count > 5000/μL. Chest X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a condition caused by the presence of microfilariae in the pulmonary circulation, leading to a severe immune response characterized by significant eosinophilia. The clinical presentation includes fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing, which are symptoms consistent with TPE. The absolute eosinophil count greater than 5000/μL further supports this diagnosis.

 

The chest X-ray finding of a miliary pattern, though more commonly associated with tuberculosis, can also be seen in TPE due to the diffuse infiltration of eosinophils in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Asthma can present with wheezing and nocturnal symptoms but is not typically associated with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray or such a high level of eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Miliary tuberculosis: Miliary tuberculosis can present with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray but is not associated with a significantly elevated eosinophil count. Miliary TB usually presents with systemic symptoms like weight loss, night sweats, and widespread dissemination in the body.

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: This condition can cause pulmonary symptoms and may present with a miliary pattern on imaging. However, it is usually a type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex-mediated) and does not typically lead to such high levels of eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is characterized by symptoms like fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, wheezing, significant eosinophilia, and a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these clinical findings, especially in endemic regions. The treatment of choice for TPE is diethylcarbamazine (DEC).

questions.text: A 48-year-old smoker presents with yellow, copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning after getting up and on changing posture. He has had this problem for a few years. What will be the first differential diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is bronchiectasis. The key features in this case include the presence of copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning and with postural changes. These features are highly suggestive of bronchiectasis, a condition characterized by chronic dilation and infection of the bronchi. This leads to the production of large amounts of sputum, particularly after changes in posture due to the drainage of secretions from the dilated airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Typically presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and a dry or mildly productive cough. Asthma is diagnosed with spirometry, showing reversible airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Pneumonia: Usually presents acutely with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It is less likely to cause symptoms that have persisted for years.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: May present with chronic cough and hemoptysis but is less likely to produce copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases with postural changes over several years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis should be considered in patients with chronic, copious, foul-smelling sputum that varies with posture, especially in the context of a history of smoking or recurrent respiratory infections. Recognizing these features can prompt appropriate diagnostic imaging, such as a CT scan showing characteristic tram-track or signet ring appearances.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisate oxidase

 

Option A. Homogentisate oxidase: This is the correct enzyme.

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase, which leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body. This acid can darken upon exposure to air, resulting in blackened urine and other symptoms.

 

It is compatible with fairly normal life. The only abnormality is the blackening of urine on standing. The homogentisic acid is oxidized by polyphenol oxidase to benzoquinone acetate. It is then polymerized to black colored alkaptone bodies.

 

By the 3rd or 4th decade of life, patient may develop ochronosis (deposition of alkaptone bodies in intervertebral discs, cartilages of nose, pinna of ear). Black pigments are deposited over the connective tissues including joint cavities to produce arthritis.

 

Diagnosis of Alkaptonuria:

 

  1. Urine becomes black on standing when it becomes alkaline. Blackening is accelerated on exposure to sunlight and oxygen. The urine when kept in a test tube will start to blacken from the top layer.
  2. Ferric chloride test will be positive for urine.
  3. Benedict’s test is strongly positive. Due to reducing nature of homogentisic acid in urine.

 

Treatment: No specific treatment is required. But minimal protein intake with phenylalanine less than 500 mg/day is recommended.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase is not associated with Alkaptonuria. It is involved in the metabolism of purines, not in the pathway related to this condition.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), a different metabolic disorder causing mousy/musty body odor.

 

Option D. Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the pyrimidine biosynthesis pathway and is not related to Alkaptonuria.

 

Educational objective:

 

The diagnosis is alkaptonuria in which urine becomes black on standing due to oxidation of homogentisic acid present in the urine. The disease is autosomal recessive inherited and it is due to the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase/dioxygenase required for further metabolism of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: The first organ to undergo Rigor mortis amongst the following options is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myocardium

 

  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis
  • It first affects the involuntary muscles starting with the myocardium
  • The order of appearance in voluntary muscles is:
    • Upper eyelids
    • Neck muscles,
    • Jaw
    • Facial muscles
    • Chest
    • Upper limbs
    • Abdomen
    • Lower limbs
    • Finger and toes
  • Order of disappearance is also the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Nysten's law, rigor mortis first affects the myocardium (heart muscle) among the listed options.

 

Rigor mortis follows the “rule of 12”- 12 hrs. to set in, remains for 12 hrs., and passes off in 12 hrs.

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost benefit analysis

 

Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): CBA is a method used to evaluate the total costs versus the total benefits of a project or decision in monetary terms. It helps determine whether the benefits of a project or decision outweigh the costs, thereby justifying the investment. This type of analysis assigns a monetary value to all outcomes, allowing for a direct comparison between costs and benefits. For example, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) might report that it saved $12 million in a given year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): Definition: CEA assesses the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action.

 

  • Output: It is measured in non-monetary terms such as health outcomes (e.g., quality-adjusted life years (QALY) saved). For instance, the NTEP might measure its effectiveness by the number of lives saved or the improvement in the quality of life.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Definition: This is a quantitative method that involves mapping out and analyzing the sequence of activities and events in a project.

 

  • Tools: It includes techniques like Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM).
  • Usage: Network analysis is used to identify the sequence of tasks, the longest path through the project (critical path), and to optimize the project schedule.

 

Option D. Input Output Analysis: Definition: This method examines the relationship between inputs and outputs in an economic system.

 

  • Application: It can include both cost-benefit and cost-effective analyses as it calculates the effects of changing inputs on the outputs. This type of analysis is often used in economics to understand how different sectors of an economy interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a program analyzed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $

 

CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a program analyzed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.

 

INPUT-OUTPUT ANALYSIS - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)

 

NETWORK ANALYSIS – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

choices.text: The presence of contralateral mediastinal lymph nodes precludes surgical resection
For patients over 70 years with advanced disease, single-agent chemotherapy is preferred
Among the Asian population, squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of NSCLC
Gefitinib shows the highest efficacy in female smokers with adenocarcinoma

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Non-Small Cell Lung Carcinoma (NSCLC) are accurate, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Among the Asian population, squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of NSCLC

 

In Asian populations, adenocarcinoma (not squamous cell carcinoma) is the most common histologic type of NSCLC. This demographic pattern is important because it correlates with the higher prevalence of EGFR mutations observed in Asian patients, which has significant implications for treatment selection and response to targeted therapies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The presence of contralateral mediastinal lymph nodes precludes surgical resection: Contralateral mediastinal lymph node involvement (N3 disease) indicates stage IIIB disease, which is generally considered unresectable. This represents locally advanced disease where surgery would not provide survival benefit.

 

Option B. For patients over 70 years with advanced disease, single-agent chemotherapy is preferred: For elderly patients (>70 years) with advanced NSCLC, single-agent chemotherapy is often preferred due to reduced toxicity while maintaining modest efficacy. This approach provides a better risk-benefit ratio in this population.

 

Option D. Gefitinib shows the highest efficacy in female smokers with adenocarcinoma: This statement is incorrect. Gefitinib, an EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, shows highest efficacy in female NON-smokers with adenocarcinoma histology. Smoking status is a critical negative predictor of response to EGFR inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epidemiology of NSCLC varies by population, with adenocarcinoma being the predominant subtype in Asian populations, associated with higher rates of EGFR mutations that impact therapeutic approaches and response to targeted therapies.

questions.text: The rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HMG CoA reductase

 

Explanation:

 

HMG CoA reductase (3-hydroxy-3-methyl-glutaryl-CoA reductase) is the rate-limiting enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. It catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a critical step in the production of cholesterol. This enzyme is a major target for statins, a class of drugs used to lower cholesterol levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 7-alpha hydroxylase: This enzyme is involved in bile acid synthesis from cholesterol, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option C. Carnitine acyltransferase I: This enzyme is involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option D. Carnitine acyltransferase II: This enzyme is also involved in fatty acid metabolism, specifically in the mitochondrial matrix, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis, making it a critical target for cholesterol-lowering therapies.

 

Note – Rate limiting enzyme of ketone bodies synthesis - HMG CoA Synthase

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer visits you with a foot swelling and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Microscopic examination of granules from the discharge was performed and is as shown in the image below. Based on this information, what can be concluded about this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

 

  • The clinical scenario, along with the presence of sulfur granules in the image, suggests a diagnosis of mycetoma. This condition can be caused by either bacteria (Actinomycetoma) or fungi (Eumycetoma).
  • Mycetoma typically occurs following a trauma, and individuals engaged in agricultural work are at higher risk of developing this condition.

 

 

Clinical features (GST):

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

 

The discharge contains granules which are microcolonies of the causative organism. It is generally more invasive and can spread via the fascial planes (NOT Lymphatic) to the underlying muscle or bone. Dissemination is rare but can occur in lesions of the head and neck.

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
    • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  2. Actinomycetoma:
    • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
    • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is lymphocyte accumulation:

While lymphocytes can be present due to the chronic inflammatory nature of mycetoma, their accumulation is not a distinctive feature of this disease.

 

Option C. Undergoes lymphatic spread:

Mycetoma primarily spreads through contiguous tissue invasion rather than lymphatic spread. This is a feature that differentiates it from other infections like lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D. Involves only superficial tissues:

This is incorrect because mycetoma can involve both superficial and deep structures, including skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria and fungi, and is characterized by the presence of grains in discharging sinuses, often involving deep tissue structures beyond superficial tissues.

 

 

 

Reference –

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 401, 604, 605

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 689

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 1338, 1688

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic patient had undergone surgery for cataract.  6 weeks post-operatively, the patient came with inflammation, decreased vision. On further examination, honeycomb appearance of retina is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid macular edema

 

The postoperative period, presence of inflammation, decreased vision, and the characteristic honeycomb appearance of the retina are indicative of CME.

 

When CME develops following cataract surgery and its cause is thought to be directly related to the surgery, it is referred to as Irvine-Gass syndrome or pseudophakic CME.

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) involves fluid accumulation within the macula, the central part of the retina, leading to swelling and cyst-like spaces, which can create a honeycomb appearance on optical coherence tomography (OCT). CME is a common complication after cataract surgery, particularly in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR (Central Serous Retinopathy): Central serous retinopathy is characterized by the accumulation of fluid under the retina, which can cause visual disturbances. It often presents with a serous detachment of the central retina. The classic appearance is not honeycomb-like, and CSR is typically not associated with inflammation.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is a serious condition where the retina peels away from its underlying layer of support tissue. The classic symptoms are the sudden appearance of floaters, flashes, and a shadow or curtain over part of the visual field. The honeycomb pattern is not characteristic of retinal detachment.

 

Option D. Diabetic Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the retina. It typically presents with dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and neovascularization. While macular edema can occur in diabetic retinopathy, the description of a postoperative honeycomb appearance of the retina is more specific to cystoid macular edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a diabetic patient presenting with postoperative inflammation and decreased vision featuring a honeycomb appearance of the retina, the likely diagnosis is cystoid macular edema.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions, inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, is characterized by the presence of large platelets and Döhle bodies in neutrophils? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. May-Hegglin Anomaly

 

Explanation: 

 

May-Hegglin anomaly is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder characterized by the presence of large platelets (thrombocytopenia) and Döhle bodies in neutrophils. Döhle bodies are small, blue-gray inclusions found in the periphery of neutrophil cytoplasm. They are composed of rough endoplasmic reticulum. This condition is classified under qualitative disorders of platelet function, specifically within the category of storage pool disorders that affect platelet function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alder-Reilly bodies - These are large, dark-purple granules found in neutrophils and other leukocytes in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis. This is not associated with large platelets and is not autosomal dominant.

 

Option B. Mucopolysaccharidosis - This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down glycosaminoglycans. It is typically autosomal recessive and characterized by Alder-Reilly bodies in leukocytes, not Döhle bodies or large platelets.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome - This is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and large peroxidase-positive granules in neutrophils. It is not associated with large platelets or Döhle bodies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

May-Hegglin anomaly is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia with large platelets and Döhle bodies (blue-gray cytoplasmic inclusions) in neutrophils, representing a distinct qualitative platelet function disorder.

questions.text: Which is a not a risk factor for Carcinoma of Gall bladder? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polyp <10 mm

 

Gallbladder polyps are growths that emerge from the lining of the gallbladder. Those that are smaller than 10 mm are generally considered less likely to be cancerous. The risk of cancer increases with the size of the polyp, especially if it is larger than 10 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Porcelain gallbladder: This condition is characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall. It has been associated with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Option B. Primary sclerosing cholangitis: This is a chronic biliary disease marked by inflammation and fibrosis of the bile ducts. People with primary sclerosing cholangitis have an elevated risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma and to a lesser extent, gallbladder cancer, especially if they develop gallbladder polyps.

 

Option D. Gallstone >3 cm: Large gallstones, especially those larger than 3 cm, have been linked with an increased risk of gallbladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While porcelain gallbladders and large gallstones are established risk factors for gallbladder cancer, and primary sclerosing cholangitis has a known association with gallbladder malignancies, small gallbladder polyps (less than 10 mm) typically represent a lower risk for cancer.

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ampulla

 

Explanation:

 

 

Ampulla:

 

  • The ampulla is the widest section of the fallopian tube and is the most common site for fertilization.
  • This region provides an optimal environment for the sperm to meet the ovum and for the subsequent fertilization process to occur.
  • The ampulla is also the most common site of ectopic pregnancy, where a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.

 

Structure of the Fallopian Tube:

 

The fallopian tube has four main parts:

 

  1. Infundibulum: The funnel-shaped opening near the ovary with finger-like projections called fimbriae.
  2. Ampulla: The widest and longest part where fertilization typically occurs.
  3. Isthmus: A narrow section adjacent to the uterus.
  4. Interstitial (or intramural): The part that traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isthmus: The isthmus is the narrow section of the fallopian tube close to the uterus. While it plays a role in the transport of the fertilized egg to the uterus, it is not the primary site for fertilization.

 

Option C. Interstitial: This portion of the fallopian tube traverses the uterine wall and opens into the uterine cavity. It is not typically where fertilization occurs.

 

Option D. Infundibular: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped opening near the ovary, equipped with fimbriae to help capture the released ovum. Fertilization does not typically occur here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, which is the widest and longest part of the tube.

 

Ref: Page no 23, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of milk production in the correct sequence: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Galactopoiesis
  2. Lactogenesis
  3. Mammogenesis
  4. Lactation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 1, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves several stages, starting from the development of the mammary glands to the actual ejection of milk. These stages are:

 

3. Mammogenesis : This is the development of the mammary glands, which begins at birth but continues significantly during puberty. The breast tissue matures and prepares for potential milk production.

 

2. Lactogenesis : This stage refers to the initiation of milk synthesis. It involves hormonal changes that stimulate the mammary glands to start producing milk. Lactogenesis typically begins during the late stages of pregnancy and continues after childbirth.

 

1. Galactopoiesis : This is the maintenance of milk production after lactogenesis has initiated. It involves the continued synthesis and secretion of milk, which is essential for sustaining milk supply during breastfeeding.

 

4. Lactation: This refers to the process of milk ejection and feeding the baby. It encompasses the baby's suckling, which stimulates further milk production and ejection through the let-down reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves mammogenesis, lactogenesis, galactopoiesis, and finally lactation.

questions.text: In a community, there were 550 births in a year out of which 50 were stillbirths. There were 09 deaths among newborns during 0-7 days of life. An additional 41 deaths occurred during 8-28 days of life. Calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality rate for the given community. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 18

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) measures the number of deaths of newborns within the first 7 days of life per 1,000 live births. It focuses specifically on early neonatal deaths, which occur during the first week of life.

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 550
  • Stillbirths: 50
  • Live births (LB): 550 - 50 = 500
  • Early Neonatal Deaths (ENND): 9 deaths during 0-7 days.

 

ENMR formula:

 

 

Therefore, the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is 18 deaths per 1,000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate is calculated as the number of early neonatal deaths (0-7 days) per 1,000 live births.

choices.text: Serum ceruloplasmin levels
Serum copper levels

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin levels

 

The image of the eye, showing a possible Kayser-Fleischer ring, along with symptoms of hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration, strongly suggests Wilson disease. Wilson disease is a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism. The initial screening test in suspected cases is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels, as ceruloplasmin is the primary copper-carrying protein in the blood, and levels are typically reduced in Wilson disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum copper levels: This test is used to further support the diagnosis after abnormalities in ceruloplasmin levels are noted. Total serum copper is typically low in Wilson disease, but free copper is elevated due to the low ceruloplasmin levels.

 

Option C. Enzyme assay: Not relevant for Wilson disease, which involves a defect in copper transport rather than an enzyme deficiency.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: Also not relevant, as Wilson disease is related to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child presenting with hepatitis and neurological symptoms, the presence of a Kayser-Fleischer ring strongly suggests Wilson disease. The first diagnostic step is to measure serum ceruloplasmin levels.

questions.text: Which of the following tests has the briefest window period for identifying HIV infection? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Nucleic acid test (NAT)

 

Explanation:

 

Nucleic acid tests (NATs) have the shortest window period for detecting HIV infection, typically identifying the virus 10-12 days after infection. NATs directly detect viral RNA in the bloodstream rather than waiting for the development of antibodies or sufficient levels of viral proteins. This makes them extremely valuable for detecting very early HIV infections, particularly in high-risk settings or when testing blood donations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibody assay: Antibody tests have a significantly longer window period of approximately 3-12 weeks after infection, as they depend on the host's immune response to produce detectable antibodies against HIV. While they are the most commonly used screening tests due to cost and availability, they cannot detect very early infections.

 

Option B. P24 antigen assay: The p24 antigen test detects the HIV p24 protein and has a window period of about 2-3 weeks after infection. While shorter than antibody tests, it's still longer than NAT. The p24 antigen is often combined with antibody testing in 4th generation assays.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is actually a type of nucleic acid testing technology used to detect HIV RNA or proviral DNA. When used for HIV RNA detection, it performs similarly to other NATs. This option represents a specific methodology rather than a distinct test category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleic acid tests have the shortest window period (10-12 days) for HIV detection and are the most sensitive for early infection, but antibody-based tests remain the mainstay for routine screening due to cost and availability considerations.

questions.text: Which tongue papillae do not have taste buds? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Filiform

 

The filiform papillae are the most numerous of the lingual papillae on the tongue, but they do not contain taste buds. They are primarily responsible for the general sensations of touch, temperature, pressure, and texture. Unlike other types of papillae—such as foliate, fungiform, and circumvallate—filiform papillae are not involved in the sensation of taste, which is a special sensory function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foliate: These papillae are located on the lateral sides of the tongue and contain taste buds. They are primarily involved in sensing sweet and sour tastes.

 

Option C. Fungiform Papilla: These are found on the top of the tongue and are involved in sensing sweet, sour, and salty tastes. They contain taste buds.

 

Option D. Circumvallate: These are located at the back of the tongue and are primarily involved in sensing bitter tastes. They also contain taste buds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds and are primarily involved in general sensations like touch and texture, not in the sensation of taste

questions.text: Corneal transplant is allowed until how much time after death? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 hours

 

Explanation:

 

  • While most organs can be transplanted, only while body is still on ventilator, and blood circulation is maintained, in case of cornea, the transplantation is possible even if a person is died at home because cornea is avascular (lacks blood supply) 
  • It Can be done up to 6 hours after death in India 
  • In western countries, can be extended up to 12 hours 
  • Time limit is shorter in India due to tropical climate causing faster decomposition 
  • Other organs require continuous blood supply and must be harvested while patient is on ventilator 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. Corneas do not deteriorate this quickly and can be used for transplantation for several hours post-mortem.

 

Option B. 2 hours: Incorrect. The minimum accepted timeframe is up to 6 hours, not just 2 hours.

 

Option C. 4 hours: Incorrect. Though corneal tissue remains viable for more than 4 hours, the standard practice extends the limit up to 6 hours in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A corneal transplant can be performed within 6 hours after death because the cornea is avascular and does not deteriorate as rapidly as other organs​

questions.text: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position). The X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.

 

In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.

 

Structures seen are:

 

  1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  2. Frontal sinuses
  3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth).
  4. Zygoma
  5. Zygomatic arch
  6. Nasal bone.
  7. Frontal process of maxilla
  8. Superior orbital fissure
  9. Intratemporal fossa.

 

Other 3 Options: Not best visualized in Water's view as this technique primarily highlights the maxillary and other larger sinuses.
 

Educational Objective:
 

Water's view is particularly effective for visualizing the maxillary sinus, making it an essential diagnostic tool in sinus imaging, especially when evaluating issues related to the maxillary sinuses.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: What is the primary function of Type II Restriction Enzymes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cut DNA at palindromic sites

 

Explanation:

 

Type II restriction enzymes cut DNA at specific sites termed palindromes. These enzymes function by recognizing and cutting DNA at specific palindromic sequences. As explained in the text, a palindrome is defined as having the same sequence on both strands when read in the 5' to 3' direction. For example, GGCC is a palindrome because when reading both strands in the 5' to 3' direction, the sequence is the same (GGCC). This specificity allows restriction enzymes to make precise cuts at defined locations in DNA molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prevent folding of proteins: This is incorrect as restriction enzymes act on DNA, not proteins. They have no direct role in protein folding or prevention of folding.

 

Option B. Remove formed DNA: Restriction enzymes do not remove or eliminate DNA; they make specific cuts at recognition sites, resulting in DNA fragments.

 

Option C. Prevent supercoiling: While some enzymes like topoisomerases are involved in managing DNA supercoiling, this is not the function of restriction enzymes. Restriction enzymes are specifically involved in cleaving DNA at recognition sequences.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type II restriction enzymes are DNA-cutting enzymes that recognize specific palindromic DNA sequences, making precise cuts at these sites, which is crucial for many molecular biology applications including DNA analysis and genetic engineering.

choices.text: Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type
Connective tissue disease of the mixed type

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most strongly associated with the presence of anti-centromere antibodies? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Syndrome characterized by CREST features.

 

Explanation: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies are highly specific for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), which is classically associated with the CREST syndrome (Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia). These antibodies show a strong association with clinical features including digital ischemic ulcers, calcinosis cutis, and isolated pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), while renal crisis is rarely seen in patients with this antibody pattern. Anti-centromere antibodies display a discrete speckled (centromere) pattern on immunofluorescence testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic sclerosis of the diffuse cutaneous type: Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc) is associated with anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, not anti-centromere antibodies. These antibody patterns are mutually exclusive in systemic sclerosis.

 

Option B. Connective tissue disease of the mixed type: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is characterized by the presence of U1-RNP antibodies. Anti-centromere antibodies are not a serological feature of MCTD.

 

Option D. Inflammatory myopathy, particularly polymyositis: PM/Scl and anti-Jo antibodies are the serological markers associated with myositis overlap syndromes. Anti-centromere antibodies are not typically found in inflammatory myopathies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anti-centromere antibodies have high specificity for limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and the CREST variant, serving as important serological markers that help distinguish this clinical phenotype from other forms of systemic sclerosis and connective tissue disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following Amino acid needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysteine

 

Cysteine is not typically restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. In fact, cysteine supplementation may be necessary in some cases because CBS deficiency can lead to a decreased ability to convert homocysteine into cysteine. However, this decision is made on an individual basis after assessing the patient's specific needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methionine: Methionine is usually restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. Since methionine is metabolized to homocysteine, limiting dietary methionine intake can help reduce homocysteine levels in these patients.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine is not typically restricted in the diet of CBS-deficient patients. It is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism, so it does not require special dietary adjustments.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is not supplied in the diet but rather accumulates in the body as a result of CBS deficiency. Managing and reducing elevated homocysteine levels is the primary goal of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram:

 

 

So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 291

questions.text: In which age group is Paget's disease of the breast not observed? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Childhood 

 

Explanation:

 

Paget's disease of the breast is a rare manifestation of breast cancer characterized by unilateral nipple eczema, nipple discharge, and scaly crust. It represents the extension of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) into the nipple epidermis without basement membrane invasion. Since breast cancer is primarily a disease of older women with 75% occurring in those over 50 years of age, Paget's disease follows this pattern and is not observed in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adolescent: While uncommon, breast cancer can occur in adolescents, making Paget's disease possible though rare in this age group.

 

Option C. Adult: Paget's disease is commonly observed in adults, as this is when breast cancer incidence rises significantly.

 

Option D. Elderly: The elderly population has the highest incidence of breast cancer, making Paget's disease relatively more common in this age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paget's disease of the breast represents underlying ductal carcinoma extending into the nipple epidermis with characteristic clinical findings of unilateral nipple eczema and discharge. It is predominantly HER2-positive (>80-90%) and HR-negative, and follows the age distribution pattern of breast cancer, being absent in childhood.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve develops from second brachial arch? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Facial nerve

 

Branchial arches are also known as pharyngeal arches
 

The facial nerve is the nerve of the 2nd pharyngeal arch.

 

The facial nerve (seventh cranial nerve) is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression. Additionally, it provides taste sensation for the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and supplies parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular, sublingual, and lacrimal glands. The facial nerve is associated with the second brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve (CN IX) arising from the medulla oblongata and is associated with the third brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It supplies sensation to the posterior third of the tongue, the upper pharynx, and the tonsil. It also has motor functions for the stylopharyngeus muscle and provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland.

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal nerve is the fifth cranial nerve (CN V) and is primarily a sensory nerve for the face, with a smaller motor component for the muscles of mastication. The nerve develops in association with the first brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It divides into three primary branches: the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves.

 

Option D. Vagal nerve: The vagus nerve is the tenth cranial nerve (CN X). It has a wide distribution and serves multiple functions in the body. Its functions include supplying motor innervation to the muscles of the pharynx and larynx, providing sensory information from the external ear and parts of the pharynx, and carrying parasympathetic fibers to thoracic and abdominal viscera. The vagus nerve is associated with the fourth (and a contribution from the sixth) brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Taking CT scan of the patient

 

Taking CT scan of the patient: Incorrect. This is not part of the primary survey. After the primary survey, if the patient is stabilized, a secondary survey is conducted which is a more thorough examination and may involve advanced imaging like CT scans to further delineate injuries.

 

Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

 

Primary survey consists of five components, remembered by the mnemonic "ABCDE":

 

  1. Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection: The first step is to ensure the patient has a patent (open) airway, and to protect the cervical spine in case of potential injury.
  2. Breathing and ventilation: This step includes assessing the patient's breathing and ventilation. This can involve checking for symmetric chest rise, listening for breath sounds, and looking for any signs of respiratory distress or chest injury.
  3. Circulation with haemorrhage control: This involves assessing the patient's circulation and looking for signs of active bleeding. Measures such as fluid resuscitation may be initiated during this step if the patient is in shock.
  4. Disability: This involves a quick evaluation of the patient's neurological status, often using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS).
  5. Exposure/Environmental control: The patient should be fully undressed to allow a complete examination. However, care should be taken to prevent hypothermia, which can worsen outcomes in trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measuring blood pressure: This is a part of assessing Circulation.

 

Option B. Removing clothes to inspect for wounds: This is a part of Exposure/Environmental control. It's crucial to remove clothing so that injuries aren't missed. However, while ensuring exposure, care should also be taken to maintain the patient's body temperature and prevent hypothermia.

 

Option D. Checking airway patency: This is part of Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection. Ensuring a clear airway is a top priority. Airway obstruction takes least time to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary survey in trauma care includes Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure/Environmental control. Advanced imaging studies like CT scans are part of the secondary survey, conducted after initial stabilization.

questions.text: Match the column: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

Peutz-Jeghers polyp (A): It is associated with STK11 (serine/threonine kinase 11) gene mutation (3). Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract along with mucocutaneous pigmentation. These polyps are typically found in the jejunum and can cause intussusception and bleeding.

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (B): It is linked to APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene mutation (1). FAP is characterized by the development of hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon, with 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer if untreated.

 

Juvenile polyposis (C): It is associated with SMAD4 gene mutation (4). Juvenile polyposis is characterized by hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, with increased risk of GI malignancies.

 

Tuberous sclerosis (D): It is linked to TSC2 gene mutations (2). Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder characterized by hamartomas in multiple organ systems, including the brain, skin, kidneys, and heart.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young male child presents with failure to pass meconium and has been diagnosed with megacolon. Which of the following layers is affected by the absence of neurons? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

The patient is likely suffering from Hirschsprung disease, a condition caused by the absence of enteric nerve plexuses due to a failure of migration of neural crest cells. This absence affects the submucosal (Meissner's) plexus and the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus, which are located in the submucosa (Layer 2) and the muscularis propria (Layer 3), respectively. The lack of these plexuses results in a failure of peristalsis and subsequent megacolon, as the affected segment of the colon cannot properly relax and move bowel contents forward.

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. Layer 1 and 4: Layers 1 and 4 correspond to the mucosa and serosa, neither of which contain the affected neural plexuses seen in Hirschsprung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung disease is characterized by the absence of the submucosal (Meissner's) and myenteric (Auerbach's) plexuses in the submucosa and muscularis propria, leading to functional obstruction and megacolon due to failure of neural crest cell migration.

questions.text: A patient was administered succinylcholine and halothane before surgery. The patient developed sudden rigidity. Core temperature was elevated to 104°F, and there was an elevation in EtCO2 as well. Which of the following is the most suitable medication to treat this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dantrolene

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario described is characteristic of malignant hyperthermia, a rare but life-threatening condition that can be triggered by volatile anaesthetic agents (like halothane) and depolarizing muscle relaxants (like succinylcholine). 

 

The classic clinical features include muscle rigidity, rapidly increasing body temperature, elevated end-tidal CO2 (due to increased metabolism) and if left untreated, can progress to rhabdomyolysis, acidosis, hyperkalemia and eventually death.

 

Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. It acts by inhibiting calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, thereby reducing the hypermetabolic state and muscle contraction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium bicarbonate: While acidosis may develop during malignant hyperthermia and sodium bicarbonate might be used as a supportive measure to correct metabolic acidosis. Dantrolene specifically targets the calcium dysregulation that is central to malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Lorazepam: This is a benzodiazepine used primarily for seizures, anxiety, and sedation. It has no role in the management of malignant hyperthermia and would not address the hypermetabolic crisis.

 

Option D. Mannitol: This is an osmotic diuretic that might be used as a supportive measure in malignant hyperthermia to prevent or treat renal failure from myoglobinuria (resulting from muscle breakdown). However, like sodium bicarbonate, it is not the specific treatment for malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant hyperthermia as a potential complication of succinylcholine and halothane administration, Dantrolene is the specific antidote and drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the following EEG finding? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM sleep

 

EEG recording is showing "Sawtooth waves" which are characteristic of REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. REM sleep is also associated with rapid eye movements, muscle atonia (paralysis), and dreaming.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Transition between wakefulness and sleep, contains theta waves.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, characterized by delta waves.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep follows NREM sleep. EEG in REM sleep shows sawtooth waves and increased activity similar to awake state (beta activity) along with return of alpha activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 534.

choices.text: Interference with implantation of fertilized ovum

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a mechanism of action of the oral contraceptive pill? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interference with placental functioning

 

Oral contraceptive pills work through multiple mechanisms, but interfering with placental functioning is not one of them. The primary mechanisms are aimed at preventing pregnancy before implantation occurs. Once placental development begins, OCPs have no effect, which is why they cannot terminate an established pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of ovulation: This is a primary mechanism of combined oral contraceptives. The hormones synergistically suppress FSH and LH release from the pituitary, preventing follicular development and ovulation.

 

Option B. Prevention of fertilization: OCPs alter cervical mucus, making it thick, viscid and scanty, which creates a barrier that prevents sperm penetration into the upper genital tract.

 

Option C. Interference with implantation: OCPs produce endometrial changes including stromal edema, decidual reaction, and regression of glands, making the endometrium non-receptive to a developing blastocyst.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oral contraceptives function exclusively by preventing the establishment of pregnancy through pre-implantation mechanisms rather than disrupting already established pregnancies or placental function.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, and abdominal pain. He reports memory loss and reveals that he works at a battery recycling plant. On examination, a noticeable foot drop in both lower extremities is seen. Laboratory testing shows elevated blood lead levels. Which enzyme is affected in the given scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase

 

The question clearly indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning (elevated blood levels and associated clinical features)

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis through inhibition of multiple enzymes involved in heme synthesis pathway, of which main inhibited enzymes are:

 

  • ALAD (Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase)- Mnemonic ALAD sounds like lead
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
  • Ferrochelatase

 

This leads to increased levels of multiple precursors of Heme production like:

 

  • Protoporphyrin
  • Coproporphyrin
  • δ-amino levulinic acid

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen III: Not directly inhibited by lead. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is involved in the conversion of hydroxymethylbilane to uroporphyrinogen III.

 

Option C. Uroporphyrinogen I: Not directly involved in lead poisoning. Uroporphyrinogen I is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway but not specifically inhibited by lead.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Not involved in the heme synthesis pathway. This enzyme is part of the metabolic pathway converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective

 

Lead poisoning primarily inhibits the enzyme Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase (ALAD), leading to disruptions in the heme synthesis pathway and accumulation of heme precursors.

questions.text: Broca's area is located in which part of the cerebral cortex? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior frontal gyrus

 

Broca's area is primarily located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, specifically within the left hemisphere. It is divided into two regions: Brodmann area 44 (Broca's area proper) and Brodmann area 45 (Pars triangularis). This region is crucial for language production, including the ability to form grammatically correct sentences and articulate speech.

 

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is typically the left hemisphere in right-handed individuals and a significant portion of left-handed individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Superior Temporal Gyrus: While the superior temporal gyrus is involved in language processing, it is not the primary site for speech production or Broca's area. Instead, the superior temporal gyrus is associated with auditory processing and speech comprehension.

 

Areas present in superior temporal gyrus: 

 

Brodmann Area 41 (Primary Auditory Cortex) is primarily responsible for the initial processing of auditory information. It receives and processes auditory signals from the ears and is involved in basic sound perception.

 

Brodmann Area 42 (Auditory Association Cortex) is involved in higher-level auditory processing. It helps in recognizing complex auditory stimuli, such as speech, music, and environmental sounds

 

Option C. Angular Gyrus: The angular gyrus, located in the parietal lobe, is involved in various functions, including reading, writing, and language comprehension. It plays a role in translating visual information into language.

 

Areas present in angular gyrus is Brodmann Area 39. It is associated with processes like reading, writing, and language comprehension. It also plays a role in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information, contributing to our ability to understand and interpret the world around us.

 

Option D. Postcentral Gyrus: The postcentral gyrus is located in the parietal lobe and is primarily associated with sensory functions, particularly somatosensory processing. It is not directly involved in speech production or language processing. Brodmann Area 3, 1, and 2 (Primary Somatosensory Cortex): These areas together make up the primary somatosensory cortex, which is located in the postcentral gyrus. It is responsible for our ability to perceive sensations such as touch, pressure, temperature, and proprioception (awareness of body position).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus.

 

  • Broca's motor speech area - (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.
  • Wernicke's area - (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.

questions.text: Nuclear signaling pathways are all except:( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rat proteins

 

Explanation

 

Rat proteins are not nuclear signaling pathways. Recombinant rat IN- is a bioactive protein used in cell culture applications.

 

Other Options:

 

Nuclear signaling pathways involve a variety of molecules and proteins that are involved in transmitting signals from the cell surface to the nucleus of the cell.

 

Option A. Caveolins are integral membrane proteins that are involved in the formation of caveolae, which are small invaginations in the plasma membrane that are involved in signal transduction.

 

Option B. NF-kB is a transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of genes involved in immune response, inflammation, and cell survival.

 

Option C. Importins are proteins that are involved in the transport of proteins into the nucleus of the cell. They bind to nuclear localization signals on proteins and facilitate their transport into the nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear signaling pathways are complex systems involving proteins that either directly regulate gene expression or facilitate the transport of molecules into the nucleus.

questions.text: Addison's disease can present with symptoms similar to which of the following disorders? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression

 

Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, is a condition where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones, specifically cortisol and aldosterone. Symptoms of Addison's disease include fatigue, muscle weakness, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. These symptoms, especially fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss, can overlap with the symptoms of depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized anxiety disorder primarily involves excessive, uncontrollable worry about everyday events. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Option C. Bipolar disorder is characterized by mood episodes, including mania (or hypomania) and depression. It may be seen in Addison’s disease, but it is rare.

 

Option D. Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is due to hypofunctioning of the adrenocortical system. It can mimic depression due to overlapping symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and low mood. It is essential to consider medical conditions that can present similarly to psychiatric disorders to ensure accurate diagnosis and treatment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 682.
